004
005package edu.wpi.first.math.controller;
006
007import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.Radians;
008import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.RadiansPerSecond;
009import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.Volts;
010
011import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.proto.ArmFeedforwardProto;
012import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.struct.ArmFeedforwardStruct;
013import edu.wpi.first.math.jni.ArmFeedforwardJNI;
014import edu.wpi.first.units.measure.Angle;
015import edu.wpi.first.units.measure.AngularVelocity;
016import edu.wpi.first.units.measure.MutVoltage;
017import edu.wpi.first.units.measure.Voltage;
018import edu.wpi.first.util.protobuf.ProtobufSerializable;
019import edu.wpi.first.util.struct.StructSerializable;
020
021/**
022 * A helper class that computes feedforward outputs for a simple arm (modeled as a motor acting
023 * against the force of gravity on a beam suspended at an angle).
024 */
025public class ArmFeedforward implements ProtobufSerializable, StructSerializable {
026  /** The static gain, in volts. */
027  private final double ks;
028
029  /** The gravity gain, in volts. */
030  private final double kg;
031
032  /** The velocity gain, in V/(rad/s). */
033  private final double kv;
034
035  /** The acceleration gain, in V/(rad/s²). */
036  private final double ka;
037
038  /** The period, in seconds. */
039  private final double m_dt;
040
041  /** The calculated output voltage measure. */
042  private final MutVoltage output = Volts.mutable(0.0);
043
044  /**
045   * Creates a new ArmFeedforward with the specified gains and period.
046   *
047   * @param ks The static gain in volts.
048   * @param kg The gravity gain in volts.
049   * @param kv The velocity gain in V/(rad/s).
050   * @param ka The acceleration gain in V/(rad/s²).
051   * @param dtSeconds The period in seconds.
052   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for kv &lt; zero.
053   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for ka &lt; zero.
054   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for period &le; zero.
055   */
056  public ArmFeedforward(double ks, double kg, double kv, double ka, double dtSeconds) {
057    this.ks = ks;
058    this.kg = kg;
059    this.kv = kv;
060    this.ka = ka;
061    if (kv < 0.0) {
062      throw new IllegalArgumentException("kv must be a non-negative number, got " + kv + "!");
063    }
064    if (ka < 0.0) {
065      throw new IllegalArgumentException("ka must be a non-negative number, got " + ka + "!");
066    }
067    if (dtSeconds <= 0.0) {
068      throw new IllegalArgumentException(
069          "period must be a positive number, got " + dtSeconds + "!");
070    }
071    m_dt = dtSeconds;
072  }
073
074  /**
075   * Creates a new ArmFeedforward with the specified gains. The period is defaulted to 20 ms.
076   *
077   * @param ks The static gain in volts.
078   * @param kg The gravity gain in volts.
079   * @param kv The velocity gain in V/(rad/s).
080   * @param ka The acceleration gain in V/(rad/s²).
081   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for kv &lt; zero.
082   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for ka &lt; zero.
083   */
084  public ArmFeedforward(double ks, double kg, double kv, double ka) {
085    this(ks, kg, kv, ka, 0.020);
086  }
087
088  /**
089   * Creates a new ArmFeedforward with the specified gains. The period is defaulted to 20 ms.
090   *
091   * @param ks The static gain in volts.
092   * @param kg The gravity gain in volts.
093   * @param kv The velocity gain in V/(rad/s).
094   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for kv &lt; zero.
095   */
096  public ArmFeedforward(double ks, double kg, double kv) {
097    this(ks, kg, kv, 0);
098  }
099
100  /**
101   * Returns the static gain in volts.
102   *
103   * @return The static gain in volts.
104   */
105  public double getKs() {
106    return ks;
107  }
108
109  /**
110   * Returns the gravity gain in volts.
111   *
112   * @return The gravity gain in volts.
113   */
114  public double getKg() {
115    return kg;
116  }
117
118  /**
119   * Returns the velocity gain in V/(rad/s).
120   *
121   * @return The velocity gain.
122   */
123  public double getKv() {
124    return kv;
125  }
126
127  /**
128   * Returns the acceleration gain in V/(rad/s²).
129   *
130   * @return The acceleration gain.
131   */
132  public double getKa() {
133    return ka;
134  }
135
136  /**
137   * Returns the period in seconds.
138   *
139   * @return The period in seconds.
140   */
141  public double getDt() {
142    return m_dt;
143  }
144
145  /**
146   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and setpoints.
147   *
148   * @param positionRadians The position (angle) setpoint. This angle should be measured from the
149   *     horizontal (i.e. if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If
150   *     your encoder does not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
151   * @param velocityRadPerSec The velocity setpoint.
152   * @param accelRadPerSecSquared The acceleration setpoint.
153   * @return The computed feedforward.
154   */
155  @Deprecated(forRemoval = true, since = "2025")
156  public double calculate(
157      double positionRadians, double velocityRadPerSec, double accelRadPerSecSquared) {
158    return ks * Math.signum(velocityRadPerSec)
159        + kg * Math.cos(positionRadians)
160        + kv * velocityRadPerSec
161        + ka * accelRadPerSecSquared;
162  }
163
164  /**
165   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and velocity setpoint assuming continuous control
166   * (acceleration is assumed to be zero).
167   *
168   * @param positionRadians The position (angle) setpoint. This angle should be measured from the
169   *     horizontal (i.e. if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If
170   *     your encoder does not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
171   * @param velocity The velocity setpoint.
172   * @return The computed feedforward.
173   */
174  @SuppressWarnings("removal")
175  @Deprecated(forRemoval = true, since = "2025")
176  public double calculate(double positionRadians, double velocity) {
177    return calculate(positionRadians, velocity, 0);
178  }
179
180  /**
181   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and setpoints assuming continuous control.
182   *
183   * @param currentAngle The current angle in radians. This angle should be measured from the
184   *     horizontal (i.e. if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel to the floor). If
185   *     your encoder does not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
186   * @param currentVelocity The current velocity setpoint in radians per second.
187   * @param nextVelocity The next velocity setpoint in radians per second.
188   * @param dt Time between velocity setpoints in seconds.
189   * @return The computed feedforward in volts.
190   */
191  @SuppressWarnings("removal")
192  @Deprecated(forRemoval = true, since = "2025")
193  public double calculate(
194      double currentAngle, double currentVelocity, double nextVelocity, double dt) {
195    return ArmFeedforwardJNI.calculate(
196        ks, kv, ka, kg, currentAngle, currentVelocity, nextVelocity, dt);
197  }
198
199  /**
200   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and setpoints assuming discrete control when the
201   * velocity does not change.
202   *
203   * @param currentAngle The current angle. This angle should be measured from the horizontal (i.e.
204   *     if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel to the floor). If your encoder does
205   *     not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
206   * @param currentVelocity The current velocity.
207   * @return The computed feedforward in volts.
208   */
209  public Voltage calculate(Angle currentAngle, AngularVelocity currentVelocity) {
210    output.mut_replace(
211        kg * Math.cos(currentAngle.in(Radians))
212            + ks * Math.signum(currentVelocity.in(RadiansPerSecond))
213            + kv * currentVelocity.in(RadiansPerSecond),
214        Volts);
215    return output;
216  }
217
218  /**
219   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and setpoints assuming discrete control.
220   *
221   * @param currentAngle The current angle. This angle should be measured from the horizontal (i.e.
222   *     if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel to the floor). If your encoder does
223   *     not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
224   * @param currentVelocity The current velocity setpoint.
225   * @param nextVelocity The next velocity setpoint.
226   * @return The computed feedforward in volts.
227   */
228  public Voltage calculate(
229      Angle currentAngle, AngularVelocity currentVelocity, AngularVelocity nextVelocity) {
230    output.mut_replace(
231        ArmFeedforwardJNI.calculate(
232            ks,
233            kv,
234            ka,
235            kg,
236            currentAngle.in(Radians),
237            currentVelocity.in(RadiansPerSecond),
238            nextVelocity.in(RadiansPerSecond),
239            m_dt),
240        Volts);
241    return output;
242  }
243
244  // Rearranging the main equation from the calculate() method yields the
245  // formulas for the methods below:
246
247  /**
248   * Calculates the maximum achievable velocity given a maximum voltage supply, a position, and an
249   * acceleration. Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal
250   * profile are simultaneously achievable - enter the acceleration constraint, and this will give
251   * you a simultaneously-achievable velocity constraint.
252   *
253   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the arm.
254   * @param angle The angle of the arm, in radians. This angle should be measured from the
255   *     horizontal (i.e. if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If
256   *     your encoder does not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
257   * @param acceleration The acceleration of the arm, in (rad/s²).
258   * @return The maximum possible velocity in (rad/s) at the given acceleration and angle.
259   */
260  public double maxAchievableVelocity(double maxVoltage, double angle, double acceleration) {
261    // Assume max velocity is positive
262    return (maxVoltage - ks - Math.cos(angle) * kg - acceleration * ka) / kv;
263  }
264
265  /**
266   * Calculates the minimum achievable velocity given a maximum voltage supply, a position, and an
267   * acceleration. Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal
268   * profile are simultaneously achievable - enter the acceleration constraint, and this will give
269   * you a simultaneously-achievable velocity constraint.
270   *
271   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the arm, in volts.
272   * @param angle The angle of the arm, in radians. This angle should be measured from the
273   *     horizontal (i.e. if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If
274   *     your encoder does not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
275   * @param acceleration The acceleration of the arm, in (rad/s²).
276   * @return The minimum possible velocity in (rad/s) at the given acceleration and angle.
277   */
278  public double minAchievableVelocity(double maxVoltage, double angle, double acceleration) {
279    // Assume min velocity is negative, ks flips sign
280    return (-maxVoltage + ks - Math.cos(angle) * kg - acceleration * ka) / kv;
281  }
282
283  /**
284   * Calculates the maximum achievable acceleration given a maximum voltage supply, a position, and
285   * a velocity. Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal
286   * profile are simultaneously achievable - enter the velocity constraint, and this will give you a
287   * simultaneously-achievable acceleration constraint.
288   *
289   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the arm, in volts.
290   * @param angle The angle of the arm, in radians. This angle should be measured from the
291   *     horizontal (i.e. if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If
292   *     your encoder does not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
293   * @param velocity The velocity of the elevator, in (rad/s)
294   * @return The maximum possible acceleration in (rad/s²) at the given velocity.
295   */
296  public double maxAchievableAcceleration(double maxVoltage, double angle, double velocity) {
297    return (maxVoltage - ks * Math.signum(velocity) - Math.cos(angle) * kg - velocity * kv) / ka;
298  }
299
300  /**
301   * Calculates the minimum achievable acceleration given a maximum voltage supply, a position, and
302   * a velocity. Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal
303   * profile are simultaneously achievable - enter the velocity constraint, and this will give you a
304   * simultaneously-achievable acceleration constraint.
305   *
306   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the arm, in volts.
307   * @param angle The angle of the arm, in radians. This angle should be measured from the
308   *     horizontal (i.e. if the provided angle is 0, the arm should be parallel with the floor). If
309   *     your encoder does not follow this convention, an offset should be added.
310   * @param velocity The velocity of the elevator, in (rad/s)
311   * @return The maximum possible acceleration in (rad/s²) at the given velocity.
312   */
313  public double minAchievableAcceleration(double maxVoltage, double angle, double velocity) {
314    return maxAchievableAcceleration(-maxVoltage, angle, velocity);
315  }
316
317  /** Arm feedforward struct for serialization. */
318  public static final ArmFeedforwardStruct struct = new ArmFeedforwardStruct();
319
320  /** Arm feedforward protobuf for serialization. */
321  public static final ArmFeedforwardProto proto = new ArmFeedforwardProto();
322}
